By clinching best picture for his comedy-drama ‚ÄòAnora‚Äô at the 97th Academy Awards, writer-director Sean Baker on Sunday became the first person to win four Oscars for the same film. He also won trophies earlier in the night for best director, original screenplay, and editing.

‚ÄúLong live independent film,‚Äù Baker, 54, said with his best picture Oscar in hand. ‚ÄòAnora‚Äô won five Oscars in total, including best actress for Mikey Madison.

Tap the link in bio to read more, via @washingtonpost. 

Photo: Mike Coppola/Getty Images

Hollywood‚Äôs biggest night never looked better, thanks to some serious style on the #Oscars red carpet. Swipe to see some of tonight‚Äôs best looks ‚Äî featuring Timmy, Cynthia Erivo, Demi Moore, and more, via @vanityfair. ‚≠êÔ∏è

Photos: Getty Images

Kieran Culkin won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in ‚ÄòA Real Pain‚Äô ‚Äî a role he nearly dropped out of, until Emma Stone, one of the film‚Äôs producers, talked him out of it with some savvy emotional blackmail. In his speech, Culkin said: ‚ÄúI have no idea how I got here. I‚Äôve just been acting my whole life ‚Äî it‚Äôs just been a part of what I do. I felt like this was never my trajectory.‚Äù

Photo: Rich Polk/Penske Media via Getty Images

In 1987, Forbes published its first billionaires list, featuring 140 individuals whose combined wealth totaled $295 billion. At the time, the richest person in the world was Japan‚Äôs Yoshiaki Tsutsumi, a real-estate tycoon worth $20 billion. 

Today, the world‚Äôs richest person, Elon Musk, is worth $419.4 billion, roughly 21 times as much as Tsutsumi at his peak and more than two million times as much as the median net worth of an American household, according to exclusive data from global wealth-intelligence firm Altrata. 

As the ranks of global billionaires have swelled dramatically in recent years, a new category of ultrarich has emerged: the superbillionaire. And on Earth, there are 24 of them.

Tap the link in bio to find out who made the cut ‚Äî and how they made their fortune, via @wsj in Apple News+.

Illustration: Kagan McLeod

‚ÄúImages shape both historical and personal memory. I want to create a personal archive for my daughter to look back on as she grows up.‚Äù
1. Bethany M. @fancybethany

‚ÄúPhotography allows us to see, celebrate and understand generations before us and leave clues for those ahead of us.‚Äù
2 + 3. Aundre L. @aundre

‚ÄúI want my work to inspire future generations to put all their ideas to the test and break boundaries when it comes to art.‚Äù
4. Isaac W. @isaacwest

‚ÄúMy family‚Äôs photo album is where I pull most of my inspiration from. My parents captured the mundane aspects of our lives, not just celebratory moments.‚Äù
5. McKayla C. @kaystackss

‚ÄúWhen history looks back at this time in Black culture, there will be a plethora of images showing the dynamic and varied range of experiences that we have.‚Äù
6. Ivan M. @eightsecs

On the morning of Sunday, Oct. 20, 1991, in the south-central Nebraska farm town of Hastings, Leo Stohler walked through Chautauqua Park, an open field surrounded by clapboard houses, wafting a metal detector over the dewy grass. Head down and following an indistinct crackle, he suddenly stumbled upon something awful lying flat in his path: a decapitated corpse wearing nothing but shoes.

Stohler recognized the body. He found a phone and called his neighbor, Gene Fleming. Fleming answered, listened, then set down the receiver. He dialed 911.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been a murder,‚Äù Fleming said. ‚ÄúSomebody get me an officer.‚Äù 

‚ÄúCalm down,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs deputy, Mike Peterson, said. ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs been murdered?‚Äù

‚ÄúAndy,‚Äù Fleming replied. ‚ÄúMy goose.‚Äù

Before his gruesome death, it seemed inevitable that Andy was on his ascent to the highest plane attainable for a goose ‚Äî or a person, for that matter ‚Äî in postindustrial America: He was on the cusp of becoming a brand. News of Andy‚Äôs death spread to his fans around the globe, but after months and no leads, the sheriff‚Äôs office declared the case still unsolved.

Tap the link in bio to read the tragic tale of the most famous bird in the country, via @nymag in Apple News+.

Photo: The Andy Archive, Andy the Goose LLC

Reality - vs - Reimagined with @openai Sora

As a resident of San Francisco, I wanted to see if I could portray my backyard as the dystopian hellscape the media often imagines. So a few Sundays ago, I took a walk around North Beach, Chinatown and the Financial District and captured some photos with my iPhone... then reimagined my favorite shots using AI.

The visual process took less than 2 hours (ironically, the longest part being sourcing all the ambient SFX for this video).

Think about what this means for location scouting... and eventually for the final frame when telling stories with deep/rich world building.

NOTE: I changed all the faces of the people included before importing into the tools.

SFX+Music: @epidemicsound 

#ai #sora #openai #sanfrancisco  #filmmaking
We asked, you answered. How have you used ChatGPT to get through tough times?

At Sunday‚Äôs Screen Actors Guild Awards, a Best Actor race that felt like Adrien Brody‚Äôs to lose (even Kieran Culkin thought so!) got shaken up by a 29-year-old in a leather suit known as Timoth√©e Chalamet. Chalamet‚Äôs performance as Bob Dylan in ‚ÄòA Complete Unknown‚Äô was the favorite among his fellow actors, and after a speech that was a little kooky, a lot sincere, and perhaps announced his plans for world domination, we‚Äôre left with the question of what this last-minute curveball might mean for the Oscar race.

Is Brody still the front-runner to win his second Oscar for his role in ‚ÄòThe Brutalist,‚Äô or does Chalamet‚Äôs insurgency in what many consider to be the most predictive precursor for actors herald an upset?

Tap the link in bio to read more, via @vulture in Apple News+.

Photo: Michael Buckner/Variety via Getty Images

Tristan Schukraft almost didn‚Äôt go to Fire Island.

A California native, the serial tech entrepreneur was in New York City on a business trip about 12 years ago when friends invited him to part of the island known as the Pines, a famous gay-vacation destination on a sliver of sand off Long Island.¬†

Schukraft was skeptical. ‚ÄúI was like, ‚ÄòThat‚Äôs not really my thing.‚Äô‚Äù he recalls. The jet-setting tech founder, now 45, prefers luxury hotels to the cramped ‚Äúshare houses‚Äù where many Fire Island vacationers stay. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre in this house with a bunch of people you don‚Äôt know ‚Äî it‚Äôs so awkward to me.‚Äù

But Schukraft went, and he ended up loving it. 

Schukraft, based in Los Angeles and then Puerto Rico, made only one other short day trip to the Pines over the next 10 years. So in May 2024, he raised eyebrows by announcing a deal to pay about $17 million for the vast majority of the Pines commercial district. 

The question on many people‚Äôs minds: What‚Äôs he going to do with it?

Tap the link in bio to read more, via @wsjmag in Apple News+.

Photo: Ryan Lowry for WSJ. Magazine

A few researchers at Anthropic have, over the past year, had a part-time obsession with a peculiar problem: Can Claude play Pok√©mon?

Early attempts were poor. In June 2024, Claude 3.5 Sonnet struggled to progress. When challenged, it repeatedly tried to run from mandatory battles. This wasn't surprising: Claude has never been explicitly trained to play any video games.

These early attempts were not without moments of levity too. On one occasion, Claude got stuck in a corner and‚Äîconvinced something must be broken‚Äîtyped out a formal request to reset the game.

With the new Claude 3.5 Sonnet in October, there was a glimmer of improvement. Claude managed to beat a rival for the first time and move beyond Pallet Town. But ultimately, progress stalled. Better, yes, but far from becoming a Pok√©mon master.

Last week, a researcher tried out an early preview of Claude 3.7 Sonnet.

The results were striking. Within hours, Claude defeated Brock. Days later, it trounced Misty. Progress that older models had little hope of achieving. Turns out extended thinking is super effective.

Where previous models wandered aimlessly or got stuck in loops, Claude 3.7 Sonnet plans ahead, remembers its objectives, and adapts when initial strategies fail. Critical skills for battling pixelated gym leaders. And, we posit, in solving real-world problems too.

So, what makes this possible? Claude was given a knowledge base to store notes, vision to see the screen, and function calls which allow it to simulate button presses and navigate the game. Together, they allow Claude to sustain gameplay with tens of thousands of interactions.

With a few tools to help it see the screen a bit better, Claude acts as an agent, applying its abilities to a novel task. In this, we start to see glimmers of AI systems that tackle challenges with increasing competence, not just through training but with generalized reasoning.

A small but enthusiastic following has formed at Anthropic, checking in on Claude's progress. Claude provides its followers daily moments of delight, like deciding to misname its Squirtle, "TSUNMAI!".

Claude Plays Pok√©mon continues on as a researcher's personal project.

üßë‚Äçüé® David Sheldrick (@davidsheldrick ) is a British Korean artist based in London, known for his background in fashion photography, a field in which he honed his skills after graduating from the London College of Fashion. His artistic pursuits often explore the intersections of beauty, nature, and technology, themes evident throughout his work. At a relatively young age, David has already distinguished himself in the photography world, earning multiple awards from prestigious organizations such as Adobe and Broncolor. 

During the COVID-19 pandemic, he expanded his repertoire by delving into AI art. His expertise in AI art has attracted high-profile clients, including Manchester City FC, Coke Studios, Standard Chartered Bank, Mercedes Benz, and Stone Mountain Georgia. Additionally, his work is sought after by popular clubs and DJs in London, highlighting his ability to blend innovative technology with creative expression to meet the dynamic needs of the entertainment and corporate sectors.

üéûÔ∏è From 18 to 21, I lived in Seoul, South Korea, after finishing secondary school in London. What began as a summer Korean course at Yonsei University grew into a three-year adventure. In a cramped dorm with other internationals, I met half-Koreans like me for the first time, bonding into our ‚Äú2AM‚Äù clique. With Sinchon and Hongdae‚Äôs nightlife on our doorstep, we dove into Seoul‚Äôs underbelly nightly. This film celebrates those endless nights, the city‚Äôs energy, and explores South Korea‚Äôs evolving beauty and wealth ideals.

üé§ ‚ÄúMy process is a brute-force approach: I work nonstop on something until I arrive at something that satisfies my needs as a body of work.‚Äù

[This film was a part of our Sora Selects showcase in New York City!]

#soraselects #sorashowcase

First, let‚Äôs lay out the facts. 

Four commercial jet crashes have occurred in the last 10 weeks. There have been several private airplane crashes in the news recently too. And that‚Äôs just what is happening in the sky ‚Äî on the ground, things appear just as chaotic. In mid-February, the Federal Aviation Administration announced that it was laying off around 400 employees.

Mars may not seem like a prime holiday spot with its arid landscape and punishing radiation levels, but it once boasted beaches, researchers have found. While previous discoveries of features including valley networks and sedimentary rocks have suggested the red planet once had flowing rivers, there has been debate among scientists over whether it also had oceans. Now researchers say they have fresh evidence to support the idea after discovering buried beaches.

‚ÄúThere had to be tides, there had to be waves, there had to be a nearby river supplying sediment, and all these things had to be active for some extended period of time,‚Äù said Dr. Benjamin Cardenas, a coauthor of the research from Penn State University.

Tap the link in bio to read more, via @guardian.

Photo: NASA/Getty Images

Silicon Valley breeds visionary ideas, and with them, communities of dreamers. But not all those ideas and communities are benevolent. It can be hard to separate harmful movements from aspirational ones ‚Äî and it‚Äôs easy to exploit those who mistake one for the other. 

Enter the ‚ÄúZizians,‚Äù a so-called ‚Äúdeath cult‚Äù whose ‚Äúpost-rationalist‚Äù leader goes by the name ‚ÄúZiz.‚Äù The Zizians are allegedly responsible for a string of violence across the country: at least six confirmed deaths ‚Äî three within the last month alone ‚Äî two alleged suicides, and one disappearance. Just last week, Ziz and another group member were arrested in Maryland, charged with multiple minor offenses. Larger indictments seem likely to follow.

Who is Ziz? How did she gain her followers? And what, exactly, do they stand for? Tap the link in bio to read more, via @voxdotcom in Apple News+.

Illustration: Paige Vickers/Vox; Getty Images

Whether for health, environmental concerns, or ethical reasons, more and more people are opting to cut meat from their diets ‚Äî even for temporary periods. But what happens to the body when meat or animal products disappear from the plate?

Recent research suggests that even short stints without meat ‚Äî whether weeks, days, or even just a few meals ‚Äî can trigger surprising changes, from gut-bacteria shifts to lower cholesterol. But the key to reaping the benefits isn‚Äôt just what you cut out ‚Äî it‚Äôs what you add in.

Tap the link in bio to read more, via @natgeo in Apple News+.

Photo: Alfred Pasieka/Science Photo Library

Oxford University Press chose ‚Äúbrain rot‚Äù as its word of the year for 2024, defining it as the ‚Äúsupposed deterioration of a person‚Äôs mental or intellectual state, especially viewed as a result of overconsumption of material (now particularly online content) considered to be trivial or unchallenging.‚Äù 

In general, ‚Äúbrain rot‚Äù can also refer to surrealist content created to entertain people whose attention spans have presumably withered away thanks to time spent scrolling, or to a general state of ‚Äúonlineness‚Äù that has rewired someone‚Äôs mind.

‚ÄúOn the one hand, talking this way is just about fitting in,‚Äù writes Kaitlyn Tiffany for @theatlantic. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a trend, like any other in the history of young people using words their parents and other authority figures don‚Äôt know. On the other, the ease with which my friends, siblings, and I slide into this mode is a bit unsettling.‚Äù

Naturally, there‚Äôs been hand-wringing over the way these linguistic quirks have bled into real life. But are they actually good for us? Tap the link in bio to read more, via @theatlantic in Apple News+.

Gabby Windey‚Äôs Jennifer Coolidge‚Äìesque intonation has served her well in her four years on reality television. In 2022, the onetime Denver Broncos cheerleader completed the ABC ultramarathon: She was a finalist on ‚ÄòThe Bachelor‚Äô season 26, coled ‚ÄòThe Bachelorette‚Äô season 19, and then took second place on season 31 of ‚ÄòDancing With the Stars.‚Äô After ‚ÄòThe Bachelorette,‚Äô she was briefly engaged to contestant Erich Schwer ‚Äî¬†but they broke up before she went on tour with ‚ÄòDWTS Live.‚Äô She performed in 60 shows in three months. 

Then, in August, the star of the most hetero show on TV came out as queer on ‚ÄòThe View.‚Äô

‚ÄúApparently all the lesbians and bi girls loved me on ‚ÄòBachelor,‚Äô‚Äù she explained on an early episode of her podcast, ‚ÄòLong Winded.‚Äô It‚Äôs like everyone knew before me.‚Äù

The status update ‚Äî and her endearing relationship with ex-Hasidic queer comedian Robby Hoffman, documented for her million Instagram and more than 700,000 TikTok followers ‚Äî boosted Windey‚Äôs profile. Next thing she knew, she found herself in a castle in Scotland, competing on the great reality-TV clearing house ‚ÄòThe Traitors‚Äô ‚Äî and becoming this season‚Äôs breakout star.
